rsbNotes.title: Acts 14:8
rsbNotes.text: 14:8 Lystra. In 6 b.c. Augustus fortified this settlement and made it into a Roman colony of the province of Galatia. He also settled the colony with Roman army veterans.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 14:10
rsbNotes.text: 14:10 he sprang up and began walking. See “Miracles” at 1 Kin. 17:22.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 14:12–13
rsbNotes.text: 14:12, 13 An ancient legend circulated in Lystra that the Greek gods Zeus and Hermes disguised themselves as men and came to the Phrygian hill country, seeking hospitality. Only one couple welcomed them, and in return their cottage was changed into a temple with a golden roof and marble columns. The houses of those who had refused the gods were destroyed. The Lystrans may have been thinking of this legend when they welcomed Barnabas and Paul and prepared to sacrifice oxen.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 14:14
rsbNotes.text: 14:14 tore their garments. A conventional sign of grief or distress.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 14:15–17
rsbNotes.text: 14:15–17 The content of Paul’s sermon is similar to his later sermon at Athens (17:22–31). Both sermons were addressed to pagan crowds who would not understand quotations from and explanations of Old Testament Scriptures. Paul stressed that God’s creative and providential power extended everywhere. See “General Revelation” at Ps. 19:1.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 14:16
rsbNotes.text: 14:16 allowed all the nations. See “Mankind’s Guilty Knowledge of God” at Rom. 1:19.

rsbNotes.title: Acts 14:20
rsbNotes.text: 14:20 Derbe. A Lycaonian border town in southeastern Galatia, sixty-five miles southeast of Lystra.
